results.title: What I have written
results.creator_credit: Beyond Films, Early Works, Peter Sainsbury and John Hughes
results.brief_description:
Australian marital drama, which explores notions of identity and fidelity. Sorel and Christopher’s marriage is in the process of recovering from an extended period of alienation, when Christopher, a writer and poet, suffers an apparently fatal stroke. Shortly afterwards Sorel receives a manuscript written by her husband, of which she knows nothing. To her chagrin it reads as a thinly veiled account of their disintegrating marriage and a recent affair of her husband’s conducted whilst they were holidaying in Paris. Sorel reads Christopher’s novella and discovers his secret erotic yearnings for others and disgust for her. But is it true? Sorel can only hopelessly rage at her comatose husband whilst attempting to unravel their past. Assuming a sophisticated style, the film utilises stills, black and white photography, and a shifting voiceover to convey a multi-layered narrative. But despite its stylish aesthetic, an over reliance on such devices, which attempts to instil the mise-en-scene with a sense of mystery and eroticism, stagnates the narrative and exacerbates the

Credits: Producer, Peter Sainsbury, John Hughes ; director, John Hughes ; writer, John A. Scott ; photography, Dion Beebee ; music, David Bridie, John Phillips, Helen Mountford ; editing, Uri Mizrahi.
Cast: Angie Milliken, Jacek Koman, Fiona Stewart, Gillian Jones, Martin Jacobs.

results.title: What have you done with my country (A)
results.creator_credit: Cinetel Film Production Services, Douglass Baglin and Frank Heimans
results.brief_description: Shows what has happened to the land of the first Australians after the Europeans found it and settled it less than 200 years ago. It deliberates on the present state of the Aborigines who have no rights to land and whose culture is overshadowed by the white man’s. Includes readings from Kath Walker’s “We are going”, archival drawings of early European settlement, historical newsreel footage (Vietnam moratorium marches, mining and minerals boom, technological and industrial development etc.) Also emphasises the devastation to the animal world through man’s continual development of the natural environment for commercial gain. Photography by Douglass Baglin, narrated by Tim Elliott.

results.title: What happens when you're sick?
results.creator_credit: Alfred Higgins Productions and Michael Heldman
results.brief_description: Shows why we experience symptoms such as fever, sneezing, upset stomach and diarrhoea when we’re sick and symptoms such as bleeding, swelling, and pain when we’re injured.

results.title: What happens inside?
results.brief_description: Uses animation and live action to record growth of a fertilised mammal egg. The terms gestation, umbilicus and placenta are explained. Shows birth of a litter of kittens and compares mother’s care of kittens to that of humans. Describes the first four months of human foetal development. From the series “Family living and sex eduation”.

results.title: What goes into the blast furnace?
results.creator_credit: Merton Park, Frank A. Hoare and John Durst
results.brief_description: The manner in which the raw materials used in a blast furnace - iron ore, coke and limestone - are crushed, blended and otherwise prepared before use in a furnace. Animated diagrams explain the use of a continuous hot air blast.

results.title: What goes around comes around
results.creator_credit: Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television and Jeremy Ducker
results.brief_description: When Fabian, a reclusive young man who lives and works in a laundrette, meets Lolita, there is only one obstacle to his new found love - his mother who lives upstairs. Gradually he conquers her jealousy and wrath as well as his own insecurities as Lolita teaches him more about himself and his relations with others. Lolita collapses stereotypes and frees him from the suffocating influence of his mother. This is a light hearted and comical film with none the less powerful messages.

results.title: What do you mean I've changed?: journeys through post-natal depression
results.brief_description: One in five women suffer from Post-natal depression (PND). In this short documentary, 3 women; Cindy Picton-Barnes, Susan King and Sandi Avery frankly discuss their experiences with PND - the physical and mental symptoms, self-doubt, fear and anxiety, and the treatment they found most effective. Also includes discussion with the womens’ partners and an expert from the Dona Maria Pre and Post-natal Support Network who outlines where women can go for help as well as what factors contribute to PND. Presented by Wendy Harmer, Patron of Dona Maria Post-Natal Support Network.

results.title: What do you know?: screen quiz No. 1
results.brief_description: A humorous film in a slightly slapstick style of a trivia quiz show. Asks such questions as: What is the weight of a dry Australian rules football? Where are a crab’s teeth found? Can a horse sleep standing up? etc. Relevent shots are shown relating to each question and choice answers are provided with a counting down clock. Includes footage of Melbourne, including Swanston and Collins Streets, and a game of Australian Rules football (Carlton vs Collingwood?). Interesting film from an historic point of view. Photography by David J. Bilcock. Written and narrated by Norman Ellis.
